figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc: Experimental design. Schematic illustration of the synthesis of Cu@SiO 2 core-shell nanospheres.

figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc: Representative TEM images of the (a,b) Cu/Commercial SiO 2 , (c,d) 2 , and (e,f) free Cu NPs.

figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc:
Powder X-ray diffraction patterns for the (a) Cu@SiO 2 , (b) Cu/
Commercial SiO 2 , and (c) free Cu NPs.

figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc:
Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the Cu@SiO 2

figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc:
Hydrogen generation from the hydrolysis of AB (0.2 M, 5 mL)
in the presence of different catalysts at 298 K (Cu/AB 5 0.09).

figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc:
(a) Hydrogen generation from the hydrolysis of AB (0.2 M, 5 mL) by the Cu@SiO 2 core-shell nanospheres at 298-316 K (Cu/AB 5 0.09).
(b) The Arrhenius plot (ln k vs. 1/T).

1. Schlapbach, L. & Zuttel, A. Hydrogen-storage materials for mobile applications.
Nature 414, 353-358 (2001).
2. Chen, P., Xiong, Z., Luo, J., Lin, J. & Tan, K. L. Interaction of hydrogen with metal
nitrides and imides. Nature 420, 302-304 (2002).

figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc:
Hydrogen generation from the hydrolysis of HB (0.2 M, 5 mL)
in the presence of different catalysts at 298 K (Cu/HB 5 0.09).

figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc:
Percent of initial catalytic activity retained in the successive
runs for the hydrolysis of AB and HB in the presence of Cu@SiO 2 core-
shell nanospheres at 298 K (Cu/(AB or HB) 5 0.09).
